replies.text: Your table is missing a key piece of data, analysts usually give 12 month price targets, so how accurate did the analysts price turn out to be 12 months later? Also some websites chart out in a graph both what the analysts average price target was, and where the stocks price went overtime. When you do this for some stocks, like T for example, it shows that analysts consistently call it pretty undervalued, and yet the stock also consistently under performs the market andor loses value. By your logic stocks like T would have been a good buy, even though history shows that you would have lost a lot of money in it. On the flipside meanwhile stocks like NFLX and TSLA would have been called dreadful and highly overvalued investments by analysts at various points, when it was actually the best time to buy those supposedly overpriced stocks.

Ill be honest its really not. I came to knowast year that NVDA was priced above 700 pre split but I was scared and only invested in QQQM. It then crossed 1000. I read about analyst ratings about ISRG. I invested a small amount after some research. It has gone 20 since then and has been solid despite tech sell off. I think analyst ratings is helpful to screen companies and not go tits up. I think what is usually lost is that they give a price range and typically most of us dont take risk into account and just invest blindly.
Its a site where they aggregate analyst price targets for a large number of stocks. They keep track of how accurate each analyst is for a specific stock so you get a sense of who you should follow.

Its called momentum, you rode a trade that everyone was on and it kept rising just like when Tesla was hit before and other stocks before they stagnate or decline. Analysts are also chasing the hype since very few had 700 upside target on Nvidia before it tripled they keep adjusting depending on the flowtrend
All analysts literally do is move their price targets as the stock goes up and down. It literally is useless information

Not true. Take a look at stock OTGLY. Its video game company CD Project. It has gone up 40 in last 3 months. Yet I researched and 8 analysts think it is a sell and 4 say it is a buy. I still invested because I follow the company and think there is a significant upside and current analyst opinions are recency bias. So I believe analyst opinions are a piece of information. If you blindly follow then you might get burned but using their opinion as a piece of information to screen stocks is valuable.
If analysts truly had a crystal ball why the hell would they give such valuable information away for free?

Agreed. There are also good and bad analysts. I often read reports even from what I consider good services and shake my head at times when its a field I know a lot about. To reiterate, Its a data point. If all the analysts predict a thing even if its wrong it will affect prices.

... They dont. Analysts get paid. And they are supposed to give honest projections. Its not some scam like you guys believe it is. They research the companies, speak to insiders and try to project where the stock price will be in 12 months. They can be spot on with revenue and earnings projections and still be way off on the stock price. Thats the stock market

No one has crystal ball. Again I find it is useful to screen stocks. To follow their arguments for prices. Regarding other question I agree that it cant be 100 right. But some of the opinions are behind paywall. But you still get to see the consensus buysellhold. Also some banks etc are publicly traded right? So they have to be atleast somewhat open about their investments and cant just make shit up. Again we need to do our own research at the end of the day.

I mean analyst is not a protected job description so there is a range, but yes real analysts are good at analyzing the businesses. That the stock market is highly regarded makes share price harder to gauge.

OP is holding bags. The techniques they use to protect the system are the simpliest ... mainly blacklists and whitelists. Thats ignoring XDRs machine learning, behavioral analytics, device protection profiles, the fact that you can ingest firewall alerts into XDR, etc. Oh wow you can completely bypass AV as an admin!? You know what else you can do as an admin, uninstall the AV software. BlackHat speaker was basically farming career karma for explaining how a product works, which good for him, probably looks great on his resume. NGAVs. They all work relatively the same. They all rely on MITRE techniques tactics and procedures along with IOCs to blockalert on bad behavior. The idea that one company has secret sauce when malware has relied on many of the same fundamental software vulnerabilities for decades is rediculous and I will die on that hill. I have used both CS and XDR. Both have pros and cons.

The threat model might be limited yeah but again to me its just an example of how poor ONE of their product is, think about the rest if they build stuff this way. Cortex literally showing you what regex it uses to prevent you from executing a command? Like how they dont know you shouldnt show this info? All of configuration files in plain sight that basically reveals the internals of the product.

Their PANOS has a long history of being a source of vulnerabilities that were exploited You can say this to all companies selling appliances NetApp, HPE, Cisco, Juniper, Check Point,... The thing is they all run Linux bundled with lots of ancient packages that have CVEs showing ups all the time. Enterprises and security pentest shops perform scanning regularly plus monitor CVE database, once anything shows up theyll turn their attention to appliances they own and publish reports. Not to say their stock is overpriced or not, I no longer follow this market closely.

Customer and revenue means that they are good at selling it and their product is good. You dont get to their level without a good product. One vulnerability in a module that represents 10 of their revenue is not enough to predict a market change. Again, youre just shilling S and its super clear.

OP is not wrong in his DD though, he also didnt say he know the play for PANW, so I see no harm here. Im not an AI or endpoint Security expert but I guess even with AIbased engine, the model still need to be updated regularly to deal with new malwares behavior. Otherwise, it will cause a lot of false negative.

I am holding bags because I did my DD and came up with a thesis I believe in, not the other way around. I did not randomly buy S and then started searching to confirm any bias. I do not deny PANW and CRWD are market leaders now, but I do not believe they will keep that spot forever and Im making a bet on who I think is going to be next up there. Do not misinterpret this as SELL ALL YOUR CRWD PANW!!! BOOO THE END IS NEAR kind of thing. CRWD and PANW are profitable companies now with solid fundamentals, but their success is rooted in an era that is coming to an end in my opinion. Another thing I didnt mention is that I want to capture the massive growth a small cap stock as S can provide, a growth that CRWD and PANW cant provide because their growthexpansion phase is done.

I start by buying the longest dated leap that is the most ITM option. In this case 11626 270 c. at the time. Then and heres where I do it wrong.... I try selling a week or two out and about two spots ITM. So like 10.00 in the money. Ill also look for resistance levels and try to be near where I would expect it to drop after a run up The plan being to sell about 1000 every week or two and have an income of 20004000 a month. of course that plan never happens, in this case because I would have to roll up and out almost every time, because the underlying was just going up too fast Thinking about it more, I should probably have started selling calls now instead of selling out of the position, because I think its already close to its peak for the near future, and might go to 380ish max. But also you should NOT sell 1 or 2 weeks out. I just read that I should be doing 45 DTEs and then closing rolling when they get to 30 DTE. Car insurance is 100 euro per month fuel is like 3 times as expensive as the US, other insurances probably another 50. Fuck bikes, if god existed and wanted me to bike he wouldnt have let people invent internal combustion engines. Oh my contract automatically tracks inflation. Some funsies Income tax does go up to 52 here though, so my employer pays out part of my salary in mealcheques which is subtracted from your gross before the taxman comes. So my groceries are untaxed except for VAT. Same with ecocheques which you can spend on green things, and Consumption cheques which you can spend on just about anything. Its some weird government facilitated tax evasion scheme. More funnies No capital gains tax in Belgium as long as you dont do daytrading or speculativehigh risk trading. Its not really so simple as rates go down, markets go up, and you have to see the larger market context. In a strong growth environment, rate cuts might typically give a stock market boost, but in a weakening soft landing economy, they can do the opposite, a brief spike up and reversal notwithstanding. Additional rate cuts can precede even more market drop, but there truly isnt a direct universal correlation, because its about larger context. Look at 2007, which is a similar analog to today in some ways prior to rate cuts in Sept, the market dropped 23 weeks and we may see that again here, then markets surged on the cut announcement, went up to new all time highs which we may also see again here as of SeptOct, like SP to 5800? 5900?. After the all time high peak, stocks then started their 18 month drop, even as rates kept dropping in salvage mode. Here now, the SP could easily touch 3900 into next year before a strong rebound, based on chart setups. No guarantees of course, but hence why I think its best to wait and watch a bit, risk is legitimately high going forward here. Watch the bond rates too, which are a leading indicator to the Fed funds rate or watch TLT going upward ahead as an inverse, it is set up to continue a new up trend. Fed rate changes always lag, but the bond rates dropping are also cluing in a weak economy ahead, not strong. Rate cuts in this environment actually reduce govt interest expenditure which is a massive source of liquidity that gets funneled into markets, essentially draining liquidity that the markets need to keep going up, and spurredon private borrowing on lower rates if it even happens isnt going to overpower that in a weakening environment. Similar to 2007 as well, and 2000, the technical chart pattern itself in each major index, SPX, NQ, RTY is now one of completing a multiyear run pattern, and at a large degree scale, not midrun or starting a new run. I think a lot of people feel like its 201617 about to repeat, rather than 2000 or 200708. But this is a different market context now than the last 1012 years, much more akin to 2007 in pattern, or more so 2000 in context and aftermath or even 1929, but I doubt we see any straight plunge like 29, more like a grind down and up with multiple plunges. There are no crystal balls obviously, just correlated clues and patterns, but together it hints at a rough riskreward skew going forward, and a rough frustrating and quite volatile buyandhold environment for the next decade, like holding through the 1970s or 2000s, maybe worse, though there would surely be some very strong swings upward.

Part of the 1.4 is a bond ladder for the first 5 years so that youre not withdrawing anything from your port for at least the first 5 years. This protects you from the potential of a terrible downswing in the market. The biggest way you can get into to trouble with your retirement money is to be withdrawing a large amount each year while the market is tanking. Its the worstcase scenario. To avoid this, you have a bond ladder that covers you for the first 5. Sure, youll have the vast majority of the money in VOO or VTSAX and then assuming returns are decent, youll be golden. In my case, the 1.4 has to do with the HCOL area that I live in. Im in a city in California where an extremely mediocre 32 1500 sq. ft. home goes for like 900k.

Sir this is where you come to learn how to lose grandmas pension.
Calls
Options, not stock.

So a single option lets you control 100 shares. Right now target is trading for 160. You can buy a 160 call that expires tomorrow for about 150 the 150 is called premium. That 150 gives you the option tomorrow to buy 100 shares at 160 no matter what the price is. Lets say it jumps another 16 so now its trading at 185 tomorrow. Well you have right to buy 100 shares at 160 and since its trading at 185 you automatically are up 25 185160 a share or 2500 for the option. This is how the gain percentage looks crazy compared to the 16. You spent 150 and made 2500. You basically are up 1566 on your 150. Now lets say the opposite happens. It tanks to 145. Well tomorrow you still have the option to buy those shares at 160, but obviously you wouldnt since you can buy it at 145 market rate. So you just let it expire and you lose your 150 you spent to have the option to buy. Puts are the opposite, but to keep it simple most people start by understanding calls since it seems more intuitive for whatever reason. There are legitimate strategies to minimize risk with options, but around here people just use them because of the high reward and relatively low risk only being able to lose the premium. Welcome to the casino.

A call option is a contract between a buyer and a seller to purchase a certain stock at a certain price up until a defined expiration date. However, most people here dont exercise options like explained above, they just buy and sell them. They move updown a lot more than the underlying stock. If you want to learn more, just YouTube options trading for beginners or something

People who know what they are talking about never and I mean never just say page fault by itself, unless they are referring to the process of accessing virtual memory behind the scenes which is the almost universal context. If you meant a program generating an unhandled exception leading to a segfault, due to accessing memory they werent given access to by the OS, then anyone who knows what they are talking about, prepends invalid to page fault. But even then thats not really the language anyway, you sound like a noob. Heres a protip about yours truly. I never, ever, talk about anything unless I have checked my facts first. If you have ever done any Windows systems programming which I have and its obvious you havent, you would know they universally use that specific language in their kernel error codes. This is the error message from the Crowdstrike outage The PAGE_FAULT_IN_NONPAGED_AREA bug check has a value of 0x00000050. This indicates that invalid system memory has been referenced. Typically the memory address is wrong or the memory address is pointing at freed memory Source one of many and just the first hit I found Full list of BSOD error codes showing they exclusively use the language PAGE_FAULT when describing these cases This again shows your lack of even basic readinglanguage skills as an invalid page fault would be a doublenegative in this context and imply a valid access to memory. The correct usage would be A critical page fault kernel error is an invalid reference to system memory. Whereas an invalid page fault in a nonpaged area would be a valid reference to system memory. Im guessing you are so clueless that you dont understand the context of a PAGE FAULT has a different meaning when used in kernel error codes referencing nonpaged memory vs describing a page fault due to attempting to access virtual memory that has been swapped to disk. And these are logged as well as informational error codes. Ill add that a BSOD is desired behavior in this case as you dont want a bad kernel driver writing to random pages as that would lead to data corruption which is way worse. Second no, running in kernel space is not required. Running in user space and communicating with an OSprovided service running in kernel space made for that purpose, is the much safer albeit marginally slower way to do it. You are the posterboy for the DunningKruger Effect as you have just transparently telegraphed to me that you have literally zero experience working on forensic investigations involving APT threat actors or even have any experience working with NextGen EDR clients. Including specifically Crowdstrike, as they in particular do not market to zeroes like yourself. You dont know what the software actually does because you have never used it. First of all, Crowdstrike isnt exclusively an antivirus product. It operates as a kernel mode rootkit by design, as it can be configured to log extensive system information about all running processes. Such system calls, disknetwork access, etc. Second, you are absolutely, 100 correct that Microsoft could expose a safe usermode API to allow a system process running as Administrator to access all the same information. However, there is a big problem with that because the bad guys in general and APT actors in particular will write kernelmode rootkits that not only can trivially evade usermode detectionlogging, they can actively spoof systems calls and replace error codes see StuxNet for example. So instead of disabling the usermode EDR product which could be detected, they could hijack it and inject whatever they want via their kernel rootkit. So do shut up already with your droning claims of expertise already and go get a macbook, it will protect you from running thirdparty stuff in kernel mode by default. I think you need that. Already have one and I hate to break it to you but the vast majority of InfoSec peeps run nix. Either OsX or Linux. I have a windows gaming laptop, which is fine, but I dont use it for anything other than entertainment.
